case_name: Calcutta Dock Labour Board v. Jaffar Imam, Brindaban Nayak and Jambu Patra

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 569 to 571 of 1964 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 569 to 571 of 1964. Appeals from the judgment and orders dated August 4, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeals from Original Orders Nos. 22, 29 and 30 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and orders dated August 4, 1961 of Calcutta High Court in Appeals from Original Orders Nos. 22, 29 and 30 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and orders dated August 4, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeals from Original Orders Nos. 22, 29 and 30 of 1959. Sen and S. N. Mukherjee, for the appellants. R. Chaudhuri, for the respondents.

facts.text: Three writ petitions filed by respondents Jaffar Imam, Brindaban Nayak and Jambu Patra against Calcutta Dock Labour Board on Original Side of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals arise out of three writ petitions filed by the three respondents, Jaffar Imam, Brindaban Nayak and Jambu Patra, respectively on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court against the appellant, the Calcutta Dock Labour Board.

facts.text: Each respondent challenged validity of order terminating his employment as registered dock worker by Calcutta Dock Labour Board.

anchor.surface_text: Each one of the respondents challenged the validity of the order passed by the appellant, terminating his employment as a registered dock worker with the appellant, on the ground that the said order was illegal and inoperative.

facts.text: Writ petitions claimed enquiry before termination did not afford reasonable opportunity to defend, violating natural justice and statutory provisions.

anchor.surface_text: The basis on which the impugned orders were challenged was that the enquiry which had been held before passing the said orders had number afforded to the respondents a reasonable opportunity to defend themselves and as such, the principles of natural justice had number been followed and even the relevant statutory provisions had been companytravened.

facts.text: Writ petitions of Jaffar Imam and Jambu Patra heard by Sinha J., writ of Brindaban Nayak by P.B. Mukherji J.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions filed by Jaffar Imam and Jambu Patra were heard by Sinha, J., whereas the writ petition filed by Bridaban Nayak was heard by P.B. Mukherji, J.

facts.text: Single Judges rejected writ petitions, upholding termination orders.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judges who heard these respective writ petitions substantially took the same view and rejected the companytentions raised by the respondents. In the result, the writ petitions were dismissed.

facts.text: Division Bench of Calcutta High Court allowed appeals, quashed termination orders, issued writ.

anchor.surface_text: Against these decisions, the respondents preferred appeals before a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court. The Division Bench has allowed the appeals and has issued an appropriate writ directing that the impugned orders by which the employment of the respondents was terminated by the appellant should be quashed.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from Calcutta High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the said High Court and it is with the certificate thus granted to it that it has companye to this Court in appeal.

facts.text: Respondents were dock workers attached to Port of Calcutta, registered in Reserve Pool.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the three respondents were Dock workers at- tached to the Port of Calcutta and were registered in the Reserve Pool.

facts.text: On August 12, 1955, Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, passed detention order under s.3(1)(a)(ii) of Preventive Detention Act, 1950 against respondents for violent and riotous behaviour, assault, prejudicial to public order.

anchor.surface_text: On August 12, 1955, the Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, passed an order under s. 3 1  a  ii  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950  No. 4 of 1950   hereinafter called the Act  directing that the respondents should be detained, as he was satisfied that they were guilty of violent and riotous behaviour and had companymitted assault and as such, it was necessary to detain them with a view to preventing them from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Respondents made representations to State Government under s.7 of the Act alleging untrue grounds and malafide detention.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then made representations to the State Government under s. 7 of the Act alleging that the grounds set out in the detention orders passed against them were untrue and that their detention was in fact malafide.

facts.text: Representations forwarded by State Government to Advisory Board under s.9.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of these representations, they were forwarded by the State Government to the Advisory Board under s. 9.

facts.text: Advisory Board considered representations and material, submitted report against respondents within time under s.10(1).

anchor.surface_text: When the Advisory Board received the representations made by the respondents, it took into account the material placed before it, companysidered the said representations, and submitted its report within the time specified by s. 10 1 . Since the report was against the respondents, their detention was companyfirmed by the State Government under s. 11 of the Act

facts.text: Detention confirmed by State Government under s.11, continued for about 11 months.

anchor.surface_text: Since the report was against the respondents, their detention was companyfirmed by the State Government under s. 11 of the Act and in companysequence, their detention was companytinued for about 11 months.

facts.text: After release from detention, respondents applied for allocation to registered dock employment.

anchor.surface_text: After they were released from detention, they applied for allocation to registered dock employment, but instead of passing orders in favour of such allocation, the appellant companymenced disciplinary proceedings against them

facts.text: Calcutta Dock Labour Board served show cause notices to respondents why services should not be terminated on 14 days notice under clause 36(2)(d) of Calcutta Dock Workers Regulation of Employment Scheme, 1951, on ground of detention.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant companymenced disciplinary proceedings against them and numberices were served on them to show cause why their services should number be terminated on 14 days numberice in terms of clause 36 2  d  of the Calcutta Dock Workers  Regulation of Employment  Scheme, 1951  hereinafter called the Scheme . The principal ground in these numberices was that the respondents had been detained for acts prejudicial to the maintenance of public order and as such, their services were liable to be terminated.

facts.text: Deputy Chairman of appellant not satisfied with representations, terminated services of respondents on December 17, 1956, gave 14 days wages in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the respondents showed cause against the proposed order, but the Deputy Chairman of the appellant was net satisfied with their representations, and so, he terminated their services on December 17, 1956. While doing so, each one of them was given 14 days wages in lieu of numberice for the equivalent period,.

facts.text: Respondents appealed termination to Chairman of appellant, appeals dismissed, orders confirmed on April 4, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents challenged this decision by preferring appeals to the Chairman of the appellant, but their appeals did number succeed and the orders passed by the Deputy Chairman were companyfirmed on April 4, 1957.

facts.text: Writ petitions filed against appellate orders of Chairman confirming termination.

anchor.surface_text: It is against these appellate orders that the respondents filed the three writ petitions which have given rise to the pre- sent appeals.

facts.text: Deputy Chairman and Chairman treated detention orders as equivalent to conviction due to confirmation by Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that both the Deputy Chairman who passed the im- pugned orders against the respondents, and the Chairman of the appellant who heard the respondents appeals, have taken the view that the orders of detention passed against the respondents, in substance, amounted to orders of companyviction and as such, the appellant was justified in terminating the respondents employment.

facts.text: Single Judges Sinha J. and P.B. Mukherji J. upheld termination, viewing detention and Advisory Board approval as justifying disciplinary action.

anchor.surface_text: The two learned single Judges who heard the respective writ petitions substantially took the same view. Sinha, J. has observed that the respondents had a hearing before a very responsible body and the report that went against them showed that the detaining authority was justified in holding that the respondents were guilty of the charges and had thus companymitted acts of indiscipline and misconduct within the meaning of the Scheme.

facts.text: Division Bench held appellant acted illegally on mere suspicion based on detention, quashed orders.

anchor.surface_text: The Court of Appeal which heard the three appeals filed by the respondents against the respective orders passed by the two learned single Judges has disagreed with the approach adopted by them in dismissing the respondents writ petitions. It has held that in acting merely on suspicion based on the fact that the respondents had been detained, the appellant had acted illegally and that made the impugned orders invalid and inoperative.

facts.text: In disciplinary enquiry, no notice of specific allegations given to respondents, no evidence led, relied only on detention orders.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in the present enquiry, the respondents were number given numberice of any specific allegations made against them, and the record clearly shows that numberevidence was led in the enquiry at all. It is only the detention orders that were apparently produced and it is on the detention orders alone that the whole proceedings rest and the impugned orders are founded.

facts.text: Supreme Court held termination orders invalid for lack of proper enquiry complying with natural justice and Scheme clauses 36(3) 1951 and 45(6) 1956.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, we feel numberhesitation in holding that the Court of Appeal was perfectly right in setting aside the respective orders passed by the two leaned single Judges when they dismissed the three writ petitions filed, by the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals arise out of three writ petitions filed by the three respondents, Jaffar Imam, Brindaban Nayak and Jambu Patra, respectively on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court

issues.text: Whether the enquiry held before passing the termination orders afforded a reasonable opportunity to the respondents to defend themselves, or violated principles of natural justice and relevant statutory provisions?

anchor.surface_text: The basis on which the impugned orders were challenged was that the enquiry which had been held before passing the said orders had not afforded to the respondents a reasonable opportunity to defend themselves and as such, the principles of natural justice had number been followed and even the relevant statutory provisions had been companytravened.

issues.text: Whether the appellant was justified in acting upon suspicion against the respondents based solely on their preventive detention orders confirmed after consultation with the Advisory Board?

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the question which falls to be companysidered is whether the appellant can successfully companytend that it was justified in acting upon suspicion against the respondents, the basis for the suspicion being that they were detained by orders passed by the appropriate authorities and that the said orders were companyfirmed by the State Government after companysultation with the Advisory Board.

issues.text: Whether a preventive detention order confirmed by the Advisory Board amounts to a conviction or guilt finding sufficient to justify termination of employment without a proper disciplinary enquiry?

Whether the disciplinary proceedings conducted by the appellant constituted a proper enquiry in compliance with natural justice and the Scheme clauses requiring opportunity to show cause, evidence, and defence?

anchor.surface_text: Such an enquiry is prescribed by the requirements of natural justice and an obligation to hold such an enquiry is also imposed on the appellant by clause 36 3 of the Scheme of 1951 and cl. 45 6 of the Scheme of 1956. It appears that in the present enquiry, the respondents were number given numberice of any specific allegations made against them, and the record clearly shows that numberevidence was led in the enquiry at all.

issues.text: Whether the appellant, as a statutory body exercising disciplinary power to terminate employment, was required to follow principles of natural justice as in quasi-judicial proceedings?

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that when the appellant purports to exercise its authority to terminate the employment of its employees such as the respondents in the present case, it is exercising authority and power of a quasi-judicial character. In cases where a statutory body or authority is empowered to terminate the employment of its employees, the said authority or body cannot be heard to say that it will exercise its powers without due regard to the principles of natural justice.

holdings.text: There can be no doubt that when the appellant purports to exercise its authority to terminate the employment of its employees such as the respondents in the present case, it is exercising authority and power of a quasi-judicial character.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that when the appellant purports to exercise its authority to terminate the employment of its employees such as the respondents in the present case, it is exercising authority and power of a quasi-judicial character.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory body terminating employment under scheme exercises quasi-judicial power; precedents like Associated Cement and Ridge v Baldwin apply.

holdings.text: In cases where a statutory body or authority is empowered to terminate the employment of its employees, the said authority or body cannot be heard to say that it will exercise its powers without due regard to the principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: In cases where a statutory body or authority is empowered to terminate the employment of its employees, the said authority or body cannot be heard to say that it will exercise its powers without due regard to the principles of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disciplinary power to terminate requires adherence to natural justice as per established tests for such proceedings.

holdings.text: It would... be entirely erroneous and wholly unsafe to treat the opinion expressed by the Advisory Board as amounting to a judgment of a criminal court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Advisory Board enquiry lacks cross-examination, evidence testing; not judicial or quasi-judicial like criminal trial.

holdings.text: The main infirmity which has vitiated the impugned orders arises from the fact that the said orders equate detention of a detenu with his conviction by a criminal court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Detention order, even confirmed, not equivalent to conviction; cannot form sole basis for termination.

holdings.text: In the present enquiry, the respondents were not given notice of any specific allegations made against them, and the record clearly shows that no evidence was led in the enquiry at all. It is only the detention orders that were apparently produced and it is on the detention orders alone that the whole proceedings rest and the impugned orders are founded.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in the present enquiry, the respondents were not given notice of any specific allegations made against them, and the record clearly shows that no evidence was led in the enquiry at all. It is only the detention orders that were apparently produced and it is on the detention orders alone that the whole proceedings rest and the impugned orders are founded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record shows no specific notice, no evidence led, reliance solely on detention orders violates scheme and natural justice.

holdings.text: Such an enquiry is prescribed by the requirements of natural justice and an obligation to hold such an enquiry is also imposed on the appellant by clause 36(3) of the Scheme of 1951 and cl. 45(6) of the Scheme of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Such an enquiry is prescribed by the requirements of natural justice and an obligation to hold such an enquiry is also imposed on the appellant by clause 36 3  of the Scheme of 1951 and cl. 45 6  of the Scheme of 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme clauses and natural justice mandate notice of allegations, evidence, cross-examination, defence opportunity before conclusion.

holdings.text: We feel no hesitation in holding that the Court of Appeal was perfectly right in setting aside the respective orders passed by the two learned single Judges when they dismissed the three writ petitions filed by the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, we feel no hesitation in holding that the Court of Appeal was perfectly right in setting aside the respective orders passed by the two learned single Judges when they dismissed the three writ petitions filed, by the respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Improper enquiry vitiates termination orders; Division Bench correctly quashed them upholding writs.

holdings.text: One of the basic postulates of the rule of law... is that no citizen shall lose his liberty without a fair and proper trial according to law...
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule of law prohibits deprivation of livelihood based solely on detention without fair disciplinary trial.

holdings.text: The circumstance that the respondents happened to be detained can afford no justification for not complying with the relevant statutory provision and not following the principles of natural justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Practical difficulties in enquiry do not permit bypassing mandatory procedure; rule of law prevails over expediency.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that when the appellant purports to exercise its authority to terminate the employment of its employees such as the respondents in the present case, it is exercising authority and power of a quasi-judicial character.

That being so, we feel no hesitation in holding that the Court of Appeal was perfectly right in setting aside the respective orders passed by the two learned single Judges when they dismissed the three writ petitions filed

anchor.surface_text: In cases where a statutory body or authority is empowered to terminate the employment of its employees, the said authority or body cannot be heard to say that it will exercise its powers without due regard to the principles of natural justice.
